questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that includes Microsoft Intune.

You have an update ring named UpdateRing1 that contains the following settings:

• Automatic update behavior: Auto install and restart at a scheduled time
• Automatic behavior frequency: First week of the month
• Scheduled install day: Tuesday
• Scheduled install time: 3 AM

From the Microsoft Intune admin center, you select Uninstall for the feature updates of UpdateRing1.

When will devices start to remove the feature updates?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct.
Windows devices start removal of updates as soon as they receive the change in Intune policy. Update removal isn't limited to maintenance schedules, even when they're configured as part of the update ring.
REF: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings#uninstall

comments.content: Thanks for the Microsoft link and clarification!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct. The Uninstall command doesn't consider any schedules and will immediately start removing features. Also, it force restarts your device without giving you the ability to delay the restart.

Selected Answer: B
B. as soon as the policy is received

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/windows-10-update-rings#uninstall:~:text=When%20you%20use%20the%20Uninstall%20option%2C%20Intune%20passes%20the%20uninstall%20request%20to%20devices%20immediately.

choices.B: as soon as the policy is received
choices.D: the first Tuesday of the next month
choices.A: when a user approves the uninstall

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Given answer is correct.
REF: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/client-management/mdm/policy-csp-controlpolicyconflict#mdmwinsovergp

comments.content: Have you checked Administrative templates? If you are unable to find override group policy settings feature in administrative template, then you can choose custom.
That's it, you can look it up in Intune > Device Configuration Profiles > Administrative Templates > Turn off Local Group Policy Objects processing.

B is correct:

This policy setting prevents Local Group Policy Objects (Local GPOs) from being applied.

By default, the policy settings in Local GPOs are applied before any domain-based GPO policy settings. These policy settings can apply to both users and the local computer. You can disable the processing and application of all Local GPOs to ensure that only domain-based GPOs are applied.

If you enable this policy setting, the system does not process and apply any Local GPOs.

If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, Local GPOs continue to be applied.

Note: For computers joined to a domain, it is strongly recommended that you only configure this policy setting in domain-based GPOs. This policy setting will be ignored on computers that are joined to a workgroup.

Setting type: Device

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Here's why:

Administrative Templates device profiles in Microsoft Intune allow you to configure a wide range of settings, similar to Group Policy settings. When applied, these profiles can take precedence over Group Policy settings on enrolled devices.

Selected Answer: B
Intune --> Devices --> Configuration --> Create New Policy --> Windows 10- and later --> Setting catalog --> Create --> Add settings --> search for (Control Policy Conflict) --> Tick (MDM Wins Over GP) --> Select (The MDM policy is used and the GP policy us blocked).

Selected Answer: C
C. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create an Administrative Templates device profile.
Administrative Templates device profiles in Microsoft Intune allow you to configure a wide range of settings, similar to Group Policy settings. When applied, these profiles can take precedence over Group Policy settings on enrolled devices.

Selected Answer: A
GPO: Computer Configuration > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > MDM
> "MDM Policy Refresh" > "Enable MDM Wins Over GPO"
As of now there is available in settings catalogue already, but since not in the option then I would go on the custom. B.

comments.content: Agreed, just checked. It's not in the Administrative Templates, but it is available in the settings catalogue.

discussion.content:
C

Therefore, creating an Administrative Templates device profile in Intune is the best option to attempt to override conflicting Group Policy settings with Intune policies.
currently found in settings catalog

Selected Answer: B
The option where MDM wins over GP is not found in Settings Catalogue > Administrative Templates but instead in Settings Catalogue > Control Policy Conflict. 
So in the given options, B is the correct answer.

To ensure that the settings configured in Microsoft Intune override the Group Policy settings, you should create a custom device profile from the Microsoft Intune admin center (Option B).

In this custom device profile, you need to define a custom policy named ControlPolicyConflict/MDMWinsOverGP

C. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create an Administrative Templates device profile.

Functionality: Administrative Templates in Intune are similar to Group Policy settings and allow you to manage settings on Windows 10 devices through Intune.
Overrides Group Policy: By configuring these settings in Intune, you can ensure they take precedence over local Group Policy settings

The other options do not override GPOs
https://www.anoopcnair.com/mdm-wins-over-gpo-group-policy-intune-policy/

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Sign in to the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center (Endpoint.Microsoft.coom)
Select Devices -> Windows -> Configuration profiles > Create profile.
In Create Profile, You can select Platform: Windows 10 and later and Profile: Select Settings catalog (preview).
Click on Create button.
In Configuration Settings, select Add settings and use the following search keyword “MDM Wins Over GP.” You need to choose the MDM Wins Over GP policy from the list.

https://www.anoopcnair.com/mdm-wins-over-gpo-group-policy-intune-policy/#:~:text=Option%20%231%20(New%20Method)%20%E2%80%93%20Intune%20Settings%20Catalog%20%7C%20Create%20MDM%20Wins%20Over%20GPO%20Policy

Selected Answer: C
In my viewpoint, custom profile can do more than just over-ride GPO settings. However, our first priority will be using the built-in features which you can already find in Administrative templates and even you can then see the stats such as which GPOs were implemented, which were not or which made conflict. I would say custom profiles should be used if we can't find the settings we require all in one place or is not available in the built-in options.

Selected Answer: B
B. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create a custom device profile.

Ref: https://www.anoopcnair.com/mdm-wins-over-gpo-group-policy-intune-policy/#:~:text=Option%20%231%20(New%20Method)%20%E2%80%93%20Intune%20Settings%20Catalog%20%7C%20Create%20MDM%20Wins%20Over%20GPO%20Policy

The key is the wording here: "You need to ensure that the settings configured in Microsoft Intune override the Group Policy settings." This means GPO setting MUST be applied but when it conflicts with Intune, Intune should prevail. Option "C" can "Turn off Local Group Policy Objects processing." which stops ALL GPO to be processed, so this NOT what the scenario describes here. (mdmwinsovergp can be set via Settings Catalog as well btw)
I'm not certain that the Admin Template answer is actually the correct because its really found in the Settings Catalog and doesn't outright credit itself as an Administrative Template

Selected Answer: B
B seems correct

Selected Answer: B
Although B can do the same , A standard template is available in C

Selected Answer: C
To ensure that the settings configured in Microsoft Intune take precedence, you can create an Administrative Templates device profile in the Microsoft Intune admin center. This allows you to configure the settings and policies for Windows 10 devices directly through Intune, ensuring that they override any conflicting Group Policy settings.

comments.content: MDM Wins over GP is below Admin Templates, but it is not under the Admin templates tree though.

discussion.content: Admin templates > control policy conflict > MDM Wins over GP (The MDM policy is used and the GP policy is blocked)

To ensure that the settings configured in Microsoft Intune policies override the Group Policy settings for Windows 10 devices enrolled in Intune, you should do the following:

C. From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create an Administrative Templates device profile.

questions.question_text:
You have a hybrid deployment of Azure AD that contains 50 Windows 10 devices. All the devices are enrolled in Microsoft Intune.

You discover that Group Policy settings override the settings configured in Microsoft Intune policies.

You need to ensure that the settings configured in Microsoft Intune override the Group Policy settings.

What should you do?

choices.A: From Group Policy Management Editor, configure the Computer Configuration settings in the Default Domain Policy.
choices.C: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create an Administrative Templates device profile.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Intune admin center, create a custom device profile.
choices.D: From Group Policy Management Editor, configure the User Configuration settings in the Default Domain Policy.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Intune Suite.

You use Microsoft Intune to manage devices.

You need to ensure that the startup performance of managed Windows 11 devices is captured and available for review in the Intune admin center.

What should you configure?

discussion.content:
D. an Intune data collection policy

An Intune data collection policy allows you to collect performance and diagnostic data from managed devices. This includes data related to startup performance, which can then be reviewed in the Intune admin center.

Here's why the other options are not suitable for this task:

A. the Azure Monitor agent: While the Azure Monitor agent can capture various performance metrics and logs, it is not directly managed through Intune and is more commonly used in Azure environments for broader monitoring and diagnostics.

B. a device compliance policy: Compliance policies are used to ensure devices meet specific security and configuration requirements. They do not capture performance metrics.

C. a Conditional Access policy: Conditional Access policies control access to resources based on certain conditions but do not handle performance data collection.
currently is called windows health monitoring policy -> endpoint analytics

Selected Answer: D
From Microsoft's own Copilot -
The Azure Monitor Agent (AMA) can collect a wide range of data from the guest operating system of Azure and hybrid virtual machines, including performance data1. However, it doesn’t directly monitor or display the startup performance of a device21.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. 
Keyword to look for: "for review in the Intune admin center".

Selected Answer: D
D. an Intune data collection policy. Here's why:

 Azure Monitor agent: While this agent collects performance data, it focuses on Azure resources, not individual devices managed by Intune.
 Device compliance policy: These policies focus on ensuring devices meet security and configuration requirements, not collecting specific data like startup performance.
 Conditional Access policy: These policies determine user access to resources, not data collection on devices.
 Intune data collection policy: This is the specifically designed option for capturing various data points from managed devices, including startup performance metrics. You can configure this policy to collect boot and sign-in times, application launch times, and overall device health data.

Therefore, to capture and review startup performance of managed Windows 11 devices in the Intune admin center, you need to configure an Intune data collection policy.

Selected Answer: D
D. an Intune data collection policy.

Similar to how Log Analytics Workspaces work, you need a data collection rule/policy to forward data from the source (Windows 11 devices) to a datastore (aka database or workspace). 

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/data-collection#:~:text=For%20Intune%2Dmanaged%20devices%2C%20this%20step%20configures%20the%20Intune%20data%20collection%20policy.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/data-collection#:~:text=totalBootTimeInMilliseconds%3A%20Total%20boot%20time

Selected Answer: D
D. an Intune data collection policy
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/configuration/windows-health-monitoring#create-the-profile

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D:
This is how you do it: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/configuration/windows-health-monitoring
Option : A

Selected Answer: D
Given answer isn't correct. The azure monitoring agent can be used to collect Windows event logs for example.
Answer is D.
REF: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/data-collection
To ensure that the startup performance of managed Windows 11 devices is captured and available for review in the Intune admin center, you should configure an Intune data collection policy.

Selected Answer: D
D. an Intune data collection policy

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/analytics/enroll-intune#bkmk_onboard

The way I see the answers. Please correct me if I am wrong:
1: Yes, The update will be installed on Wednesday after 1 PM because the policy applies to the device.
2: No, If a device is excluded from a software update policy and an update is available for download, the device will not install the update automatically.
3: No, The device was not enrolled as a supervised device ( enrolled via the company portal) so the policy will not apply meaning the device will not update automatically.

comments.content: and for device 3 can not be enrolled in Sunday as policy finish S.aturday

discussion.content:
I agree with the answer.

Second device, does not recieve the policy because of exclusion group.
Third device, is not supervised, so you cannot control updates.

Answer is right

Q1 > Yes Wednesday after 1PM (because of the OUTSIDE of scheduled time)
Q2 > No (because of the Group 2, exclude go over include, least rights)
Q3 > No (Because of the Company portal app, not added to ADE)
can anyone explain why the answer 1 is yes please? why not update immediately on Tuesday?

comments.content:
Q1- yes, because:
- Device1 is part of Group1 (which is included )
-the update runs during the specified timeframe (Tuesday - which is between Monday and Friday)
Why not immediately? - it isn't relevant, could be multiple reasons (no Internet connectivity), important is to be in the specified time frame (Monday-Wednesday, Friday-Saturday, with the timestamp of course)
its because it can only install outside of the schedules time which is untill wednesday

2: Device 2 is in the included and excluded group, but excluded takes precedence. So there is no applicable update policy for it.

3: You can only manage software updates for iOS/iPad devices that are enrolled through Apple's Automated Device Enrollment (ADE).

discussion.content: can anyone please explain this : why second and third is No ?

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Intune deployment that contains the resources shown in the following table.

//IMG//


You create a policy set named Set1 and add Comply1 to Set1.

Which additional resources can you add to Set1?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Comply2 and Conf1 only

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets

Selected Answer: C
You can add all types of policies and they can be cross platform, however. "Policy sets supports a subset of Intune App, Policy and Platform types. If an app or policy type is not available in the Policy Set picker experience, it is not officially supported." 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets
it say additional resources is not conf1 include in comply1?

comments.content: When you create a policy set, you don't have to choose a particular OS. You just have to apply it to a group which can have devices with different OS.

From the Microsoft Learn Page: "Policy sets support Windows, Android, macOS, and iOS/iPadOS settings, and can be assigned cross-platform."

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets

So given Answer C is correct.

discussion.content:
please correct me - my answer is A-conf1 only
reason comply 2 even though it is device compliance policy it is applied to ios/ipad the orignal set 1 includes win10 and later already added . is it possible to create set with compliance policys of two different OS ? please comment .. thankyou :)

Selected Answer: C
After my own research in my test tenant, C is the answer.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets#:~:text=You%20can%20include,Settings%20catalog%20policies

C. Comply2 and Conf1 only

You can include the following management objects in a policy set:

Apps
App configuration policies
App protection policies
Device configuration profiles
Device compliance policies
Windows autopilot deployment profiles
Enrollment status page
Settings catalog policies

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets#:~:text=You%20can%20include,Settings%20catalog%20policies

Selected Answer: C
C - policy sets can be assigned cross-platform
it can include also app policy named office 1 but not listed in possible answers
cant contain CA policies
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/fundamentals/policy-sets

C - can't add CA1 or Office policies to sets according to MS Learn materials
